context: [5] A rabbit polyclonal antibody against the VP1 N-terminal unique region of MVM (VP1 residues 1 to 141) was obtained from Susan Cotmore and Peter Tattersall, Yale University. [6] In antibody microinjection studies, normal mouse immunoglobulin G (IgG) (Sigma, St. Louis, Mo.) was used as a control. [1] The exposure of the 3â€² end of the viral genome was detected by polymerase extension. [2] Capsids treated with urea or heat as described above were washed in Microcon filter units (10-kDa retention) (Millipore, Bedford, Mass.) and then incubated with modified T7 DNA polymerase (Sequenase; Amersham Life Science, Cleveland, Ohio)-0.2 mM deoxynucleoside triphosphates-5 Î¼Ci of [32P]dATP-10 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5)-50 mM NaCl-2 mM MgCl2 for 45 min. [3] The samples were electrophoresed in a 1% agarose gel, which was then dried and exposed to X-ray film. [1] Neutralization by antibodies outside or inside the cell.For neutralization assays, various amounts of either anti-VP1-2-13 or the rabbit anti-VP1 unique region antibody were incubated with 105 TCID50s of CPV for 1 h at 37Â°C. [2] Each virus-antibody combination was then diluted and titrated in a TCID50 assay in NLFK cells.
